Theory Propaedeutics

(*  Title:       Conservation of CSP Noninterference Security under Sequential Composition
    Author:      Pasquale Noce
                 Security Certification Specialist at Arjo Systems, Italy
                 pasquale dot noce dot lavoro at gmail dot com
                 pasquale dot noce at arjosystems dot com
*)

section "Propaedeutic definitions and lemmas"

theory Propaedeutics
imports Noninterference_Ipurge_Unwinding.DeterministicProcesses
begin

text â€¹
\null

\emph{To our Lord Jesus Christ, my dear parents, and my "little" sister,}

\emph{for the immense love with which they surround me.}

\null

In his outstanding work on Communicating Sequential Processes \cite{R4}, Hoare has defined two
fundamental binary operations allowing to compose the input processes into another, typically more
complex, process: sequential composition and concurrent composition. Particularly, the output of the
former operation is a process that initially behaves like the first operand, and then like the
second operand once the execution of the first one has terminated successfully, as long as it does.
In order to distinguish it from deadlock, successful termination is regarded as a special event in
the process alphabet (required to be the same for both the input processes and the output one).

This paper formalizes Hoare's definition of sequential composition and proves, in the general case
of a possibly intransitive policy, that CSP noninterference security \cite{R2} is conserved under
this operation, viz. the security of both of the input processes implies that of the output process.

This property is conditional on two nontrivial assumptions. The first assumption is that the policy
do not allow successful termination to be affected by confidential events, viz. by other events not
allowed to affect some event in the process alphabet. The second assumption is that successful
termination do not occur as an alternative to other events in the traces of the first operand, viz.
that whenever the process can terminate successfully, it cannot engage in any other event. Both of
these assumptions are shown, by means of counterexamples, to be necessary for the theorem to hold.

From the above sketch of the sequential composition of two processes @{term P} and @{term Q},
notwithstanding its informal character, it clearly follows that any failure of the output process
is either a failure of @{term P} (case A), or a pair @{term "(xs @ ys, Y)"}, where @{term xs} is a
trace of @{term P} and @{term "(ys, Y)"} is a failure of @{term Q} (case B). On the other hand,
according to the definition of security given in \cite{R2}, the output process is secure just in
case, for each of its failures, any event @{term x} contained in the failure trace can be removed
from the trace, or inserted into the trace of another failure after the same previous events as in
the original trace, and the resulting pair is still a failure of the process, provided that the
future of @{term x} is deprived of the events that may be affected by @{term x}.

In case A, this transformation is performed on a failure of process @{term P}; being it secure, the
result is still a failure of @{term P}, and then of the output process. In case B, the
transformation may involve either @{term ys} alone, or both @{term xs} and @{term ys}, depending on
the position at which @{term x} is removed or inserted. In the former subcase, being @{term Q}
secure, the result has the form @{term "(xs @ ys', Y')"} where @{term "(ys', Y')"} is a failure of
@{term Q}, thus it is still a failure of the output process. In the latter subcase, @{term ys} has
to be deprived of the events that may be affected by @{term x}, as well as by any event affected by
@{term x} in the involved portion of @{term xs}, and a similar transformation applies to @{term Y}.
In order that the output process be secure, the resulting pair @{term "(ys'', Y'')"} must still be a
failure of @{term Q}, so that the pair @{term "(xs' @ ys'', Y'')"}, where @{term xs'} results from
the transformation of @{term xs}, be a failure of the output process.

The transformations bringing from @{term ys} and @{term Y} to @{term ys''} and @{term Y''} are
implemented by the functions @{term ipurge_tr_aux} and @{term ipurge_ref_aux} defined in \cite{R3}.
Therefore, the proof of the target security conservation theorem requires that of the following
lemma: given a process @{term P}, a noninterference policy @{term I}, and an event-domain map
@{term D}, if @{term P} is secure with respect to @{term I} and @{term D} and @{term "(xs, X)"} is a
failure of @{term P}, then @{term "(ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs, ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X)"} is still a
failure of @{term P}. In other words, the lemma states that the failures of a secure process are
closed under intransitive purge. This section contains a proof of such closure lemma, as well as
further definitions and lemmas required for the proof of the target theorem.

Throughout this paper, the salient points of definitions and proofs are commented; for additional
information, cf. Isabelle documentation, particularly \cite{R6}, \cite{R7}, \cite{R8}, and
\cite{R9}.
â€º


subsection "Preliminary propaedeutic lemmas"

text â€¹
In what follows, some lemmas required for the demonstration of the target closure lemma are proven.

Here below is the proof of some properties of functions @{term ipurge_tr} and @{term ipurge_ref}.

\null
â€º

lemma ipurge_tr_length:
 "length (ipurge_tr I D u xs) â‰¤ length xs"
by (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp_all)

lemma ipurge_ref_swap:
 "ipurge_ref I D u xs {x âˆˆ X. P x} =
  {x âˆˆ ipurge_ref I D u xs X. P x}"
proof (simp add: ipurge_ref_def)
qed blast

lemma ipurge_ref_last:
 "ipurge_ref I D u (xs @ [x]) X =
   (if (u, D x) âˆˆ I âˆ¨ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks I D u xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I)
    then ipurge_ref I D u xs {x' âˆˆ X. (D x, D x') âˆ‰ I}
    else ipurge_ref I D u xs X)"
proof (cases "(u, D x) âˆˆ I âˆ¨ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks I D u xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I)",
 simp_all add: ipurge_ref_def)
qed blast

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the proof of some properties of function @{term sinks_aux}.

\null
â€º

lemma sinks_aux_append:
 "sinks_aux I D U (xs @ ys) = sinks_aux I D (sinks_aux I D U xs) ys"
proof (induction ys rule: rev_induct, simp, subst append_assoc [symmetric])
qed (simp del: append_assoc)

lemma sinks_aux_union:
 "sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs =
  sinks_aux I D U xs âˆª sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs)"
proof (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp)
  fix x xs
  assume A: "sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs =
    sinks_aux I D U xs âˆª sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs)"
  show "sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) (xs @ [x]) =
    sinks_aux I D U (xs @ [x]) âˆª sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U (xs @ [x]))"
  proof (cases "âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I")
    case True
    hence "âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs âˆª sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs).
      (w, D x) âˆˆ I"
     using A by simp
    hence "(âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I) âˆ¨
      (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs). (w, D x) âˆˆ I)"
     by blast
    thus ?thesis
     using A and True by (cases "âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I", simp_all)
  next
    case False
    hence "Â¬ (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs âˆª
      sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs). (w, D x) âˆˆ I)"
     using A by simp
    hence "Â¬ (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I) âˆ§
      Â¬ (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs). (w, D x) âˆˆ I)"
     by blast
    thus ?thesis
     using A and False by simp
  qed
qed

lemma sinks_aux_subset_dom:
  assumes A: "U âŠ† V"
  shows "sinks_aux I D U xs âŠ† sinks_aux I D V xs"
proof (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp add: A, rule subsetI)
  fix x xs w
  assume
    B: "sinks_aux I D U xs âŠ† sinks_aux I D V xs" and
    C: "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (xs @ [x])"
  show "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x])"
  proof (cases "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I")
    case True
    hence "w = D x âˆ¨ w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs"
     using C by simp
    moreover {
      assume D: "w = D x"
      obtain u where E: "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" and F: "(u, D x) âˆˆ I"
        using True ..
      have "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs" using B and E ..
      with F have "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I" ..
      hence ?thesis using D by simp
    }
    moreover {
      assume "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs"
      with B have "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs" ..
      hence ?thesis by simp
    }
    ultimately show ?thesis ..
  next
    case False
    hence "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs"
     using C by simp
    with B have "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs" ..
    thus ?thesis by simp
  qed
qed

lemma sinks_aux_subset_ipurge_tr_aux:
 "sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs) âŠ† sinks_aux I D U xs"
proof (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp, rule subsetI)
  fix x xs w
  assume
    A: "sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs) âŠ† sinks_aux I D U xs" and
    B: "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' (xs @ [x]))"
  show "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (xs @ [x])"
  proof (cases "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I", simp_all (no_asm_simp))
    from B have "w = D x âˆ¨ w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs)"
    proof (cases "âˆƒu' âˆˆ sinks_aux I' D' U' xs. (u', D' x) âˆˆ I'", simp_all)
    qed (cases "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs). (u, D x) âˆˆ I",
     simp_all)
    moreover {
      assume "w = D x"
      hence "w = D x âˆ¨ w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" ..
    }
    moreover {
      assume "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs)"
      with A have "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" ..
      hence "w = D x âˆ¨ w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" ..
    }
    ultimately show "w = D x âˆ¨ w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" ..
  next
    assume C: "Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I)"
    have "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs)"
    proof (cases "âˆƒu' âˆˆ sinks_aux I' D' U' xs. (u', D' x) âˆˆ I'")
      case True
      thus "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs)"
       using B by simp
    next
      case False
      hence "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs @ [x])"
       using B by simp
      moreover have
       "Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs). (u, D x) âˆˆ I)"
       (is "Â¬ ?P")
      proof
        assume ?P
        then obtain u where
          D: "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs)" and
          E: "(u, D x) âˆˆ I" ..
        have "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" using A and D ..
        with E have "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I" ..
        thus False using C by contradiction
      qed
      ultimately show "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I' D' U' xs)"
       by simp
    qed
    with A show "w âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" ..
  qed
qed

lemma sinks_aux_subset_ipurge_tr:
 "sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I' D' u' xs) âŠ† sinks_aux I D U xs"
by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom [symmetric] sinks_aux_subset_ipurge_tr_aux)

lemma sinks_aux_member_ipurge_tr_aux [rule_format]:
 "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs âŸ¶
    (u, w) âˆˆ I âŸ¶
    Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs. (v, w) âˆˆ I) âŸ¶
  u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)"
proof (induction xs arbitrary: u w rule: rev_induct, (rule_tac [!] impI)+, simp)
  fix u w
  assume
    A: "(u, w) âˆˆ I" and
    B: "âˆ€v âˆˆ V. (v, w) âˆ‰ I"
  assume "u âˆˆ U âˆ¨ u âˆˆ V"
  moreover {
    assume "u âˆˆ U"
  }
  moreover {
    assume "u âˆˆ V"
    with B have "(u, w) âˆ‰ I" ..
    hence "u âˆˆ U" using A by contradiction
  }
  ultimately show "u âˆˆ U" ..
next
  fix x xs u w
  assume
    A: "â‹€u w. u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs âŸ¶
      (u, w) âˆˆ I âŸ¶
      Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs. (v, w) âˆˆ I) âŸ¶
      u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)" and
    B: "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) (xs @ [x])" and
    C: "(u, w) âˆˆ I" and
    D: "Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x]). (v, w) âˆˆ I)"
  show "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V (xs @ [x]))"
  proof (cases "âˆƒu' âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs. (u', D x) âˆˆ I")
    case True
    hence "u = D x âˆ¨ u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs"
     using B by simp
    moreover {
      assume E: "u = D x"
      obtain u' where "u' âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs" and F: "(u', D x) âˆˆ I"
       using True ..
      moreover have "u' âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs âŸ¶
        (u', D x) âˆˆ I âŸ¶
        Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I) âŸ¶
        u' âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)"
       (is "_ âŸ¶ _ âŸ¶ Â¬ ?P âŸ¶ ?Q") using A .
      ultimately have "Â¬ ?P âŸ¶ ?Q"
       by simp
      moreover have "Â¬ ?P"
      proof
        have "(D x, w) âˆˆ I" using C and E by simp
        moreover assume ?P
        hence "D x âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x])" by simp
        ultimately have "âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x]). (v, w) âˆˆ I" ..
        moreover have "Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x]). (v, w) âˆˆ I)"
         using D by simp
        ultimately show False by contradiction
      qed
      ultimately have ?Q ..
      with F have "âˆƒu' âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs).
        (u', D x) âˆˆ I" ..
      hence "D x âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs @ [x])"
       by simp
      moreover have "ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs @ [x] =
        ipurge_tr_aux I D V (xs @ [x])"
       using â€¹Â¬ ?Pâ€º by simp
      ultimately have ?thesis using E by simp
    }
    moreover {
      assume "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs"
      moreover have "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs âŸ¶
        (u, w) âˆˆ I âŸ¶
        Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs. (v, w) âˆˆ I) âŸ¶
        u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)"
       (is "_ âŸ¶ _ âŸ¶ Â¬ ?P âŸ¶ ?Q") using A .
      ultimately have "Â¬ ?P âŸ¶ ?Q"
       using C by simp
      moreover have "Â¬ ?P"
      proof
        assume ?P
        hence "âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x]). (v, w) âˆˆ I"
         by simp
        thus False using D by contradiction
      qed
      ultimately have "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)" ..
      hence ?thesis by simp
    }
    ultimately show ?thesis ..
  next
    case False
    hence "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs"
     using B by simp
    moreover have "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs âŸ¶
      (u, w) âˆˆ I âŸ¶
      Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V xs. (v, w) âˆˆ I) âŸ¶
      u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)"
     (is "_ âŸ¶ _ âŸ¶ Â¬ ?P âŸ¶ ?Q") using A .
    ultimately have "Â¬ ?P âŸ¶ ?Q"
     using C by simp
    moreover have "Â¬ ?P"
    proof
      assume ?P
      hence "âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (xs @ [x]). (v, w) âˆˆ I"
       by simp
      thus False using D by contradiction
    qed
    ultimately have "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D V xs)" ..
    thus ?thesis by simp
  qed
qed

lemma sinks_aux_member_ipurge_tr:
  assumes
    A: "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (insert v U) xs" and
    B: "(u, w) âˆˆ I" and
    C: "Â¬ ((v, w) âˆˆ I âˆ¨ (âˆƒv' âˆˆ sinks I D v xs. (v', w) âˆˆ I))"
  shows "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I D v xs)"
proof (subst ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom [symmetric],
 rule_tac w = w in sinks_aux_member_ipurge_tr_aux)
  show "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª {v}) xs"
   using A by simp
next
  show "(u, w) âˆˆ I"
   using B .
next
  show "Â¬ (âˆƒv' âˆˆ sinks_aux I D {v} xs. (v', w) âˆˆ I)"
   using C by (simp add: sinks_aux_single_dom)
qed

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the proof of some properties of functions @{term ipurge_tr_aux} and
@{term ipurge_ref_aux}.

\null
â€º

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_append:
 "ipurge_tr_aux I D U (xs @ ys) =
  ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D (sinks_aux I D U xs) ys"
proof (induction ys rule: rev_induct, simp, subst append_assoc [symmetric])
qed (simp add: sinks_aux_append del: append_assoc)

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_single_event:
 "ipurge_tr_aux I D U [x] = (if âˆƒv âˆˆ U. (v, D x) âˆˆ I
    then []
    else [x])"
by (subst (2) append_Nil [symmetric], simp del: append_Nil)

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_cons:
 "ipurge_tr_aux I D U (x # xs) = (if âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I
    then ipurge_tr_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs
    else x # ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs)"
proof -
  have "ipurge_tr_aux I D U (x # xs) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U ([x] @ xs)"
   by simp
  also have "â€¦ =
    ipurge_tr_aux I D U [x] @ ipurge_tr_aux I D (sinks_aux I D U [x]) xs"
   by (simp only: ipurge_tr_aux_append)
  finally show ?thesis
   by (simp add: sinks_aux_single_event ipurge_tr_aux_single_event)
qed

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_union:
 "ipurge_tr_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs =
  ipurge_tr_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs)"
proof (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp)
  fix x xs
  assume A: "ipurge_tr_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs =
    ipurge_tr_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs)"
  show "ipurge_tr_aux I D (U âˆª V) (xs @ [x]) =
    ipurge_tr_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U (xs @ [x]))"
  proof (cases "âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (U âˆª V) xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I")
    case True
    hence "âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs âˆª sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs).
      (w, D x) âˆˆ I"
     by (simp add: sinks_aux_union)
    hence "(âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I) âˆ¨
      (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs). (w, D x) âˆˆ I)"
     by blast
    thus ?thesis
     using A and True by (cases "âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I", simp_all)
  next
    case False
    hence "Â¬ (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs âˆª
      sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs). (w, D x) âˆˆ I)"
     by (simp add: sinks_aux_union)
    hence "Â¬ (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (w, D x) âˆˆ I) âˆ§
      Â¬ (âˆƒw âˆˆ sinks_aux I D V (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs). (w, D x) âˆˆ I)"
     by blast
    thus ?thesis
     using A and False by simp
  qed
qed

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_insert:
 "ipurge_tr_aux I D (insert v U) xs =
  ipurge_tr_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I D v xs)"
by (subst insert_is_Un, simp only: ipurge_tr_aux_union ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom)

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_subset:
 "ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X âŠ† X"
by (subst ipurge_ref_aux_def, rule subsetI, simp)


subsection "Intransitive purge of event sets with trivial base case"

text â€¹
Here below are the definitions of variants of functions @{term sinks_aux} and
@{term ipurge_ref_aux}, respectively named â€¹sinks_aux_lessâ€º and â€¹ipurge_ref_aux_lessâ€º,
such that their base cases in correspondence with an empty input list are trivial, viz. such that
@{term "sinks_aux_less I D U [] = {}"} and @{term "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U [] X = X"}. These
functions will prove to be useful in what follows.

\null
â€º

function sinks_aux_less ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'd set" where
"sinks_aux_less _ _ _ [] = {}" |
"sinks_aux_less I D U (xs @ [x]) =
 (if âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I
  then insert (D x) (sinks_aux_less I D U xs)
  else sinks_aux_less I D U xs)"
proof (atomize_elim, simp_all add: split_paired_all)
qed (rule rev_cases, rule disjI1, assumption, simp)
termination by lexicographic_order

definition ipurge_ref_aux_less ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'a set â‡’ 'a set" where
"ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs X â‰¡
  {x âˆˆ X. âˆ€v âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U xs. (v, D x) âˆ‰ I}"

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the proof of some properties of function @{term sinks_aux_less} used in what follows.

\null
â€º

lemma sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less:
 "sinks_aux I D U xs = U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U xs"
by (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp_all)

lemma sinks_aux_less_single_dom:
 "sinks_aux_less I D {u} xs = sinks I D u xs"
by (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp_all)

lemma sinks_aux_less_single_event:
 "sinks_aux_less I D U [x] = (if âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I then {D x} else {})"
by (subst append_Nil [symmetric], simp del: append_Nil)

lemma sinks_aux_less_append:
 "sinks_aux_less I D U (xs @ ys) =
  sinks_aux_less I D U xs âˆª sinks_aux_less I D (U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U xs) ys"
proof (induction ys rule: rev_induct, simp, subst append_assoc [symmetric])
qed (simp del: append_assoc)

lemma sinks_aux_less_cons:
 "sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs) = (if âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I
   then insert (D x) (sinks_aux_less I D (insert (D x) U) xs)
   else sinks_aux_less I D U xs)"
proof -
  have "sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs) = sinks_aux_less I D U ([x] @ xs)"
   by simp
  also have "â€¦ =
    sinks_aux_less I D U [x] âˆª sinks_aux_less I D (U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U [x]) xs"
   by (simp only: sinks_aux_less_append)
  finally show ?thesis
   by (cases "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I", simp_all add: sinks_aux_less_single_event)
qed

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the proof of some properties of function @{term ipurge_ref_aux_less} used in what
follows.

\null
â€º

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_less_last:
 "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (xs @ [x]) X =
   (if âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I
    then ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs {x' âˆˆ X. (D x, D x') âˆ‰ I}
    else ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs X)"
by (cases "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U xs. (v, D x) âˆˆ I",
 simp_all add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_def)

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_less_nil:
 "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs (ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] X) =
  ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
proof (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_def ipurge_ref_aux_less_def sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
qed blast

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_less_cons_1:
  assumes A: "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I"
  shows "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs) X =
    ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs) (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs X)"
proof (induction xs arbitrary: X rule: rev_induct,
 simp add: ipurge_ref_def ipurge_ref_aux_less_def sinks_aux_less_single_event A)
  fix x' xs X
  assume B: "â‹€X.
    ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs) X =
    ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)
      (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs X)"
  show
   "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs @ [x']) X =
    ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) (xs @ [x']))
      (ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X)"
  proof (cases "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs). (v, D x') âˆˆ I")
    assume C: "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs). (v, D x') âˆˆ I"
    hence "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs @ [x']) X =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs) {y âˆˆ X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I}"
     by (subst append_Cons [symmetric],
      simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_last del: append_Cons)
    also have "â€¦ =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)
        (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs {y âˆˆ X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I})"
     using B .
    finally have D: "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs @ [x']) X =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)
        (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs {y âˆˆ X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I})" .
    show ?thesis
    proof (cases "(D x, D x') âˆˆ I âˆ¨ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks I D (D x) xs. (v, D x') âˆˆ I)")
      case True
      hence "ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs {y âˆˆ X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I} =
        ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X"
       by (simp add: ipurge_ref_last)
      moreover have "D x' âˆˆ sinks I D (D x) (xs @ [x'])"
       using True by (simp only: sinks_interference_eq)
      hence "ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs = ipurge_tr I D (D x) (xs @ [x'])"
       by simp
      ultimately show ?thesis using D by simp
    next
      case False
      hence "ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs {y âˆˆ X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I} =
        ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) {y âˆˆ X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I}"
       by (simp add: ipurge_ref_last)
      also have "â€¦ = {y âˆˆ ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I}"
       by (simp add: ipurge_ref_swap)
      finally have "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs @ [x']) X =
        ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)
          {y âˆˆ ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X. (D x', D y) âˆ‰ I}"
       using D by simp
      also have "â€¦ = ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs @ [x'])
        (ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X)"
      proof -
        have "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs).
          (v, D x') âˆˆ I"
        proof -
          obtain v where
            E: "v âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs)" and
            F: "(v, D x') âˆˆ I"
           using C ..
          have "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (x # xs)"
           using E by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
          hence "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs"
           using A by (simp add: sinks_aux_cons)
          hence "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)"
           using F and False by (rule sinks_aux_member_ipurge_tr)
          hence "v âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)"
           by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
          with F show ?thesis ..
        qed
        thus ?thesis by (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_last)
      qed
      finally have "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs @ [x']) X =
        ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs @ [x'])
          (ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X)" .
      moreover have "D x' âˆ‰ sinks I D (D x) (xs @ [x'])"
       using False by (simp only: sinks_interference_eq, simp)
      hence "ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs @ [x'] = ipurge_tr I D (D x) (xs @ [x'])"
       by simp
      ultimately show ?thesis by simp
    qed
  next
    assume C: "Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs). (v, D x') âˆˆ I)"
    hence "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs @ [x']) X =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs) X"
     by (subst append_Cons [symmetric],
      simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_last del: append_Cons)
    also have "â€¦ =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)
        (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs X)"
     using B .
    also have "â€¦ =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs @ [x'])
        (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs X)"
    proof -
      have "Â¬ (âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs).
        (v, D x') âˆˆ I)" (is "Â¬ ?P")
      proof
        assume ?P
        then obtain v where
          D: "v âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)" and
          E: "(v, D x') âˆˆ I" ..
        have "sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs) âŠ† sinks_aux I D U xs"
         by (rule sinks_aux_subset_ipurge_tr)
        moreover have "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs)"
         using D by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
        ultimately have "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" ..
        moreover have "U âŠ† insert (D x) U"
         by (rule subset_insertI)
        hence "sinks_aux I D U xs âŠ† sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs"
         by (rule sinks_aux_subset_dom)
        ultimately have "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs" ..
        hence "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (x # xs)"
         using A by (simp add: sinks_aux_cons)
        hence "v âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs)"
         by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
        with E have "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs). (v, D x') âˆˆ I" ..
        thus False using C by contradiction
      qed
      thus ?thesis by (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_last)
    qed
    also have "â€¦ =
      ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) (xs @ [x']))
        (ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X)"
    proof -
      have "Â¬ ((D x, D x') âˆˆ I âˆ¨ (âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks I D (D x) xs. (v, D x') âˆˆ I))"
       (is "Â¬ ?P")
      proof (rule notI, erule disjE)
        assume D: "(D x, D x') âˆˆ I"
        have "insert (D x) U âŠ† sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs"
         by (rule sinks_aux_subset)
        moreover have "D x âˆˆ insert (D x) U"
         by simp
        ultimately have "D x âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs" ..
        hence "D x âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (x # xs)"
         using A by (simp add: sinks_aux_cons)
        hence "D x âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs)"
         by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
        with D have "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs). (v, D x') âˆˆ I" ..
        thus False using C by contradiction
      next
        assume "âˆƒv âˆˆ sinks I D (D x) xs. (v, D x') âˆˆ I"
        then obtain v where
          D: "v âˆˆ sinks I D (D x) xs" and
          E: "(v, D x') âˆˆ I" ..
        have "{D x} âŠ† insert (D x) U"
         by simp
        hence "sinks_aux I D {D x} xs âŠ† sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs"
         by (rule sinks_aux_subset_dom)
        moreover have "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D {D x} xs"
         using D by (simp add: sinks_aux_single_dom)
        ultimately have "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs" ..
        hence "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U (x # xs)"
         using A by (simp add: sinks_aux_cons)
        hence "v âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs)"
         by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
        with E have "âˆƒv âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U (x # xs). (v, D x') âˆˆ I" ..
        thus False using C by contradiction
      qed
      hence "ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs @ [x'] = ipurge_tr I D (D x) (xs @ [x'])"
       by (simp only: sinks_interference_eq, simp)
      moreover have "ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs X =
        ipurge_ref I D (D x) (xs @ [x']) X"
       using â€¹Â¬ ?Pâ€º by (simp add: ipurge_ref_last)
      ultimately show ?thesis by simp
    qed
    finally show ?thesis .
  qed
qed

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_less_cons_2:
 "Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I) âŸ¹
  ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs) X =
    ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs X"
by (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_def sinks_aux_less_cons)


subsection "Closure of the failures of a secure process under intransitive purge"

text â€¹
The intransitive purge of an event list @{term xs} with regard to a policy @{term I}, an
event-domain map @{term D}, and a set of domains @{term U} can equivalently be computed as follows:
for each item @{term x} of @{term xs}, if @{term x} may be affected by some domain in @{term U},
discard @{term x} and go on recursively using @{term "ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs'"} as input, where
@{term xs'} is the sublist of @{term xs} following @{term x}; otherwise, retain @{term x} and go on
recursively using @{term xs'} as input.

In fact, in each recursive step, any item allowed to be indirectly affected by @{term U} through the
effect of some item preceding @{term x} within @{term xs} has already been removed from the list.
Hence, it is sufficient to check whether @{term x} may be directly affected by @{term U}, and remove
@{term x}, as well as any residual item allowed to be affected by @{term x}, if this is the case.

Similarly, the intransitive purge of an event set @{term X} with regard to a policy @{term I}, an
event-domain map @{term D}, a set of domains @{term U}, and an event list @{term xs} can be computed
as follows. First of all, compute @{term "ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] X"} and use this set, along with
@{term xs}, as the input for the subsequent step. Then, for each item @{term x} of @{term xs}, if
@{term x} may be affected by some domain in @{term U}, go on recursively using
@{term "ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs'"} and @{term "ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs' X'"} as input, where
@{term X'} is the set input to the current recursive step; otherwise, go on recursively using
@{term xs'} and @{term X'} as input.

In fact, in each recursive step, any item allowed to be affected by @{term U} either directly, or
through the effect of some item preceding @{term x} within @{term xs}, has already been removed from
the set (in the initial step and in subsequent steps, respectively). Thus, it is sufficient to check
whether @{term x} may be directly affected by @{term U}, and remove any residual item allowed to be
affected by @{term x} if this is the case.

Assume that the two computations be performed simultaneously by a single function, which will then
take as input an event list-event set pair and return as output another such pair. Then, if the
input pair is a failure of a secure process, the output pair is still a failure. In fact, for each
item @{term x} of @{term xs} allowed to be affected by @{term U}, if @{term ys} is the partial
output list for the sublist of @{term xs} preceding @{term x}, then
@{term "(ys @ ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs', ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs' X')"} is a failure provided that
such is @{term "(ys @ x # xs', X')"}, by virtue of the definition of CSP noninterference security
\cite{R2}. Hence, the property of being a failure is conserved upon each recursive call by the event
list-event set pair such that the list matches the concatenation of the partial output list with the
residual input list, and the set matches the residual input set. This holds until the residual input
list is nil, which is the base case determining the end of the computation.

As shown by this argument, a proof by induction that the output event list-event set pair, under the
aforesaid assumptions, is still a failure, requires that the partial output list be passed to the
function as a further argument, in addition to the residual input list, in the recursive calls
contained within the definition of the function. Therefore, the output list has to be accumulated
into a parameter of the function, viz. the function needs to be tail-recursive. This suggests to
prove the properties of interest of the function by applying the ten-step proof method for theorems
on tail-recursive functions described in \cite{R1}.

The starting point is to formulate a naive definition of the function, which will then be refined as
specified by the proof method. A slight complication is due to the preliminary replacement of the
input event set @{term X} with @{term "ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] X"}, to be performed before the items
of the input event list start to be consumed recursively. A simple solution to this problem is to
nest the accumulator of the output list within data type â€¹optionâ€º. In this way, the initial
state can be distinguished from the subsequent one, in which the input event list starts to be
consumed, by assigning the distinct values @{term None} and @{term "Some []"}, respectively, to the
accumulator.

Everything is now ready for giving a naive definition of the function under consideration:

\null
â€º

function (sequential) ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'a list option â‡’ 'a set â‡’
    'a failure"
where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U xs None X =
  ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U xs (Some []) (ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] X)" |
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U (x # xs) (Some ys) X =
 (if âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I
  then ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U
    (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs) (Some ys) (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs X)
  else ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U
    xs (Some (ys @ [x])) X)" |
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive _ _ _ _ (Some ys) X = (ys, X)"
oops

text â€¹
\null

The parameter into which the output list is accumulated is the last but one.

As shown by the above informal argument, function â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_naiveâ€º enjoys the
following properties:

\null

@{term "fst (ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U xs None X) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"}

\null

@{term "snd (ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U xs None X) = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"}

\null

@{term "âŸ¦secure P I D; (xs, X) âˆˆ failures PâŸ§ âŸ¹
  ipurge_fail_aux_t_naive I D U xs None X âˆˆ failures P"}

\null

which altogether imply the target lemma, viz. the closure of the failures of a secure process under
intransitive purge.

In what follows, the steps provided for by the aforesaid proof method will be dealt with one after
the other, with the purpose of proving the target closure lemma in the final step. For more
information on this proof method, cf. \cite{R1}.
â€º

subsubsection "Step 1"

text â€¹
In the definition of the auxiliary tail-recursive function â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_auxâ€º, the
Cartesian product of the input parameter types of function â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_naiveâ€º will be
implemented as the following record type:

\null
â€º

record ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec =
  Pol :: "('d Ã— 'd) set"
  Map :: "'a â‡’ 'd"
  Doms :: "'d set"
  List :: "'a list"
  ListOp :: "'a list option"
  Set :: "'a set"

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the resulting definition of function â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_auxâ€º:

\null
â€º

function ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux :: "('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec"
where

"ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
  ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ =
 ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
  ListOp = Some [], Set = ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] Xâ¦ˆ" |

"ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
  ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ =
 (if âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I
  then ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U,
   List = ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs, ListOp = Some ys,
    Set = ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs Xâ¦ˆ
  else ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U,
   List = xs, ListOp = Some (ys @ [x]), Set = Xâ¦ˆ)" |

"ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux
  â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = [], ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ =
 â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = [], ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ"

proof (simp_all, atomize_elim)
  fix Y :: "('a, 'd) ipurge_rec"
  show
   "(âˆƒI D U xs X. Y = â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
      ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ) âˆ¨
    (âˆƒI D U x xs ys X. Y = â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
      ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ) âˆ¨
    (âˆƒI D U ys X. Y = â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = [],
      ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ)"
  proof (cases Y, simp)
    fix xs :: "'a list" and yso :: "'a list option"
    show
     "yso = None âˆ¨
      (âˆƒx' xs'. xs = x' # xs') âˆ§ (âˆƒys. yso = Some ys) âˆ¨
      xs = [] âˆ§ (âˆƒys. yso = Some ys)"
    proof (cases yso, simp_all)
    qed (subst disj_commute, rule spec [OF list.nchotomy])
  qed
qed

text â€¹
\null

The length of the input event list of function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux} decreases in every
recursive call except for the first one, where the input list is left unchanged while the nested
output list passes from @{term None} to @{term "Some []"}. A measure function decreasing in the
first recursive call as well can then be obtained by increasing the length of the input list by one
in case the nested output list matches @{term None}. Using such a measure function, the termination
of function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux} is guaranteed by the fact that the event lists output by
function @{term ipurge_tr} are not longer than the corresponding input ones.

\null
â€º

termination ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux
proof (relation "measure (Î»Y. (if ListOp Y = None then Suc else id)
 (length (List Y)))", simp_all)
  fix D :: "'a â‡’ 'd" and I x xs
  have "length (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs) â‰¤ length xs" by (rule ipurge_tr_length)
  thus "length (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs) < Suc (length xs)" by simp
qed

subsubsection "Step 2"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t_in ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'a set â‡’ ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec"
where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_in I D U xs X â‰¡
  â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t_out :: "('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ 'a failure" where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_out Y â‰¡ (case ListOp Y of Some ys â‡’ ys, Set Y)"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'a set â‡’ 'a failure"
where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X â‰¡
  ipurge_fail_aux_t_out (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux (ipurge_fail_aux_t_in I D U xs X))"

text â€¹
\null

Since the significant inputs of function â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_naiveâ€º match pattern
â€¹_, _, _, _, None, _â€º, those of function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux}, as returned by
function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_in}, match pattern
â€¹â¦‡Pol = _, Map = _, Doms = _, List = _, ListOp = None, Set = _â¦ˆâ€º.

Likewise, since the nested output lists returned by function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux} match
pattern â€¹Some _â€º, function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_out} does not need to worry about
dealing with nested output lists equal to @{term None}.

In terms of function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t}, the statements to be proven in order to demonstrate
the target closure lemma, previously expressed using function â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_naiveâ€º and
henceforth respectively named â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_trâ€º, â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_refâ€º, and
â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_failuresâ€º, take the following form:

\null

@{term "fst (ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"}

\null

@{term "snd (ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X) = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"}

\null

@{term "âŸ¦secure P I D; (xs, X) âˆˆ failures PâŸ§ âŸ¹
  ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X âˆˆ failures P"}
â€º

subsubsection "Step 3"

inductive_set ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ::
 "('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec set"
for Y :: "('a, 'd) ipurge_rec" where

R0: "Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y" |

R1: "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
  ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y âŸ¹
 â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
  ListOp = Some [], Set = ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y" |

R2: "âŸ¦â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
  ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y;
 âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ IâŸ§ âŸ¹
 â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs,
  ListOp = Some ys, Set = ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y" |

R3: "âŸ¦â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
  ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y;
 Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I)âŸ§ âŸ¹
 â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
  ListOp = Some (ys @ [x]), Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"

subsubsection "Step 4"

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_subset:
  assumes A: "Z âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
  shows "ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Z âŠ† ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
proof (rule subsetI, erule ipurge_fail_aux_t_set.induct)
  show "Z âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y" using A .
next
  fix I D U xs X
  assume "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
    ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
  thus "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
    ListOp = Some [], Set = ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
   by (rule R1)
next
  fix I D U x xs ys X
  assume
   "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
      ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y" and
   "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I"
  thus "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs,
    ListOp = Some ys, Set = ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
   by (rule R2)
next
  fix I D U x xs ys X
  assume
   "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
      ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y" and
   "Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I)"
  thus "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
    ListOp = Some (ys @ [x]), Set = Xâ¦ˆ âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
   by (rule R3)
qed

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux_set:
 "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"
proof (induction rule: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux.induct,
 simp_all add: R0 del: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux.simps(2))
  fix I U xs X and D :: "'a â‡’ 'd"
  let
    ?Y = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
      ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ" and
    ?Y' = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
      ListOp = Some [], Set = ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] Xâ¦ˆ"
  have "?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
   by (rule R0)
  moreover have "?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y âŸ¹
    ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
   by (rule R1)
  ultimately have "?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
   by simp
  hence "ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y' âŠ† ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_subset)
  moreover assume "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y'"
  ultimately show "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y" ..
next
  fix I U x xs ys X and D :: "'a â‡’ 'd"
  let
    ?Y = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = x # xs,
      ListOp = Some ys, Set = Xâ¦ˆ" and
    ?Y' = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs,
      ListOp = Some ys, Set = ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs Xâ¦ˆ" and
    ?Y'' = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs,
      ListOp = Some (ys @ [x]), Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
  assume
    A: "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I âŸ¹
      ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y'" and
    B: "âˆ€u âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆ‰ I âŸ¹
      ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y'' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y''"
  show "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
  proof (cases "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I", simp_all (no_asm_simp))
    case True
    have "?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     by (rule R0)
    moreover have "?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y âŸ¹ âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I âŸ¹
      ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     by (rule R2)
    ultimately have "?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     using True by simp
    hence "ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y' âŠ† ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_subset)
    moreover have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y'"
     using A and True by simp
    ultimately show "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y" ..
  next
    case False
    have "?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     by (rule R0)
    moreover have "?Y âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y âŸ¹
      Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I) âŸ¹ ?Y'' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     by (rule R3)
    ultimately have "?Y'' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     using False by simp
    hence "ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y'' âŠ† ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y"
     by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_subset)
    moreover have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y'' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y''"
     using B and False by simp
    ultimately show "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y'' âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set ?Y" ..
  qed
qed

subsubsection "Step 5"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ bool"
where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs Y â‰¡
  (case ListOp Y of None â‡’ [] | Some ys â‡’ ys) @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U (List Y) =
  ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 ::
 "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'd set â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'a set â‡’
    ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ bool"
where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X Y â‰¡
  if ListOp Y = None
  then List Y = xs âˆ§ Set Y = X
  else ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (List Y) (Set Y) = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 ::
 "'a process â‡’ ('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a â‡’ 'd) â‡’ 'a list â‡’ 'a set â‡’
    ('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ bool"
where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X Y â‰¡
  secure P I D âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
  ((case ListOp Y of None â‡’ [] | Some ys â‡’ ys) @ List Y, Set Y) âˆˆ failures P"

text â€¹
\null

Three invariants have been defined, one for each of lemmas â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_trâ€º,
â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_refâ€º, and â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_failuresâ€º. More precisely, the
invariants are @{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs"},
@{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X"}, and @{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X"},
where the free variables are intended to match those appearing in the aforesaid lemmas.

Particularly:

\begin{itemize}

\item
The first invariant expresses the fact that in each recursive step, any item of the residual input
list @{term "List Y"} indirectly affected by @{term U} through the effect of previous, already
consumed items has already been removed from the list, so that applying function
@{term "ipurge_tr_aux I D U"} to the list is sufficient to obtain the intransitive purge of the
whole original list.

\item
The second invariant expresses the fact that in each recursive step, any item of the residual input
set @{term "Set Y"} affected by @{term U} either directly, or through the effect of previous,
already consumed items, has already been removed from the set, so that applying function
@{term "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (List Y)"} to the set is sufficient to obtain the intransitive
purge of the whole original set.
\\The use of function @{term ipurge_ref_aux_less} ensures that the invariant implies the equality
@{term "Set Y = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"} for @{term "List Y = []"}, viz. for the output values of
function @{term ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux}, which is the reason requiring the introduction of function
@{term ipurge_ref_aux_less}.

\item
The third invariant expresses the fact that in each recursive step, the event list-event set pair
such that the list matches the concatenation of the partial output list with @{term "List Y"}, and
the set matches @{term "Set Y"}, is a failure provided that the original input pair is such as well.

\end{itemize}
â€º

subsubsection "Step 6"

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_input_1:
 "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs
    â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1_def)

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_input_2:
 "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X
    â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2_def)

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_input_3:
 "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X
    â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None, Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3_def)

subsubsection "Step 7"

definition ipurge_fail_aux_t_form :: "('a, 'd) ipurge_rec â‡’ bool" where
"ipurge_fail_aux_t_form Y â‰¡
  case ListOp Y of None â‡’ False | Some ys â‡’ List Y = []"

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_intro_1:
 "âŸ¦ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs Y; ipurge_fail_aux_t_form YâŸ§ âŸ¹
    fst (ipurge_fail_aux_t_out Y) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
proof (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1_def ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_def
 ipurge_fail_aux_t_out_def)
qed (simp split: option.split_asm)

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_intro_2:
 "âŸ¦ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X Y; ipurge_fail_aux_t_form YâŸ§ âŸ¹
    snd (ipurge_fail_aux_t_out Y) = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
proof (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2_def ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_def
 ipurge_fail_aux_t_out_def)
qed (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_less_def split: option.split_asm)

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_intro_3:
 "âŸ¦ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X Y; ipurge_fail_aux_t_form YâŸ§ âŸ¹
    secure P I D âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
      ipurge_fail_aux_t_out Y âˆˆ failures P"
proof (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3_def ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_def
 ipurge_fail_aux_t_out_def)
qed (simp split: option.split_asm)

subsubsection "Step 8"

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_aux:
 "ipurge_fail_aux_t_form (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux Y)"
by (induction Y rule: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux.induct,
 simp_all add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_def)

subsubsection "Step 9"

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_aux:
 "Z âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y âŸ¹
  Pol Z = Pol Y âˆ§ Map Z = Map Y âˆ§ Doms Z = Doms Y"
by (erule ipurge_fail_aux_t_set.induct, simp_all)

text â€¹
\null

The lemma just proven, stating the invariance of the first three record fields over inductive set
@{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_set Y"}, is used in the following proofs of the invariance of predicates
@{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs"}, @{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X"}, and
@{term "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X"}.

The equality between the free variables appearing in the predicates and the corresponding fields of
the record generating the set, which is required for such invariance properties to hold, is asserted
in the enunciation of the properties by means of record updates. In the subsequent proofs of lemmas
â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_trâ€º, â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_refâ€º, and
â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_failuresâ€º, the enforcement of this equality will be ensured by the
identification of both predicate variables and record fields with the related free variables
appearing in the lemmas.

\null
â€º

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_1:
 "âŸ¦Z âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set (Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ);
    ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs (Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ)âŸ§ âŸ¹
  ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs Z"
proof (erule ipurge_fail_aux_t_set.induct, assumption,
 drule_tac [!] ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_aux,
 simp_all add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1_def)
  fix x xs' ys
  assume "ys @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U (x # xs') = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
   (is "?A = ?C")
  moreover assume "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I"
  hence "?A = ys @ ipurge_tr_aux I D (insert (D x) U) xs'"
   by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_cons)
  hence "?A = ys @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs')"
   (is "_ = ?B") by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_insert)
  ultimately show "?B = ?C" by simp
next
  fix x xs' ys
  assume "ys @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U (x # xs') = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
   (is "?A = ?C")
  moreover assume "âˆ€u âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆ‰ I"
  hence "?A = ys @ x # ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs'"
   (is "_ = ?B") by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_cons)
  ultimately show "?B = ?C" by simp
qed

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_2:
 "âŸ¦Z âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set (Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ);
    ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X (Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ)âŸ§ âŸ¹
  ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X Z"
proof (erule ipurge_fail_aux_t_set.induct, assumption,
 drule_tac [!] ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_aux,
 simp_all add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2_def)
  show "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs (ipurge_ref_aux I D U [] X) =
    ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
   by (rule ipurge_ref_aux_less_nil)
next
  fix x xs' X'
  assume "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs') X' = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
   (is "?A = ?C")
  moreover assume "âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I"
  hence "?A = ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs')
    (ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs' X')"
   (is "_ = ?B") by (rule ipurge_ref_aux_less_cons_1)
  ultimately show "?B = ?C" by simp
next
  fix x xs' X'
  assume "ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U (x # xs') X' = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
   (is "?A = ?C")
  moreover assume "âˆ€u âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆ‰ I"
  hence "Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ U. (u, D x) âˆˆ I)" by simp
  hence "?A = ipurge_ref_aux_less I D U xs' X'"
   (is "_ = ?B") by (rule ipurge_ref_aux_less_cons_2)
  ultimately show "?B = ?C" by simp
qed

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_3:
 "âŸ¦Z âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set (Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := Dâ¦ˆ);
    ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X (Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := Dâ¦ˆ)âŸ§ âŸ¹
  ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X Z"
proof (erule ipurge_fail_aux_t_set.induct, assumption,
 drule_tac [!] ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_aux,
 simp_all add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3_def, (rule_tac [!] impI)+)
  fix xs' X'
  assume
   "secure P I D" and
   "(xs, X) âˆˆ failures P" and
   "secure P I D âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶ (xs', X') âˆˆ failures P"
  hence "(xs', X') âˆˆ failures P"
   by simp
  moreover have "ipurge_ref_aux I D (Doms Y) [] X' âŠ† X'"
   by (rule ipurge_ref_aux_subset)
  ultimately show "(xs', ipurge_ref_aux I D (Doms Y) [] X') âˆˆ failures P"
   by (rule process_rule_3)
next
  fix x xs' ys X'
  assume S: "secure P I D" and
   "(xs, X) âˆˆ failures P" and
   "secure P I D âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶ (ys @ x # xs', X') âˆˆ failures P"
  hence "(ys @ x # xs', X') âˆˆ failures P"
   by simp
  hence "(x # xs', X') âˆˆ futures P ys"
   by (simp add: futures_def)
  hence "(ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs', ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs' X') âˆˆ futures P ys"
   using S by (simp add: secure_def)
  thus "(ys @ ipurge_tr I D (D x) xs', ipurge_ref I D (D x) xs' X') âˆˆ failures P"
   by (simp add: futures_def)
qed

subsubsection "Step 10"

text â€¹
Here below are the proofs of lemmas â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_trâ€º,
â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_refâ€º, and â€¹ipurge_fail_aux_t_failuresâ€º, which are then applied to
demonstrate the target closure lemma.

\null
â€º

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_tr:
 "fst (ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
proof -
  let ?Y = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None,
    Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
  have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y
    âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set (?Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ)"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux_set del: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux.simps)
  moreover have
   "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs (?Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ)"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_input_1)
  ultimately have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_1 I D U xs (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_1)
  moreover have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_form (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_aux)
  ultimately have "fst (ipurge_fail_aux_t_out (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)) =
    ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_intro_1)
  moreover have "?Y = ipurge_fail_aux_t_in I D U xs X"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_in_def)
  ultimately show ?thesis
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_def)
qed

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_ref:
 "snd (ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X) = ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
proof -
  let ?Y = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None,
    Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
  have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y
    âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set (?Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ)"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux_set del: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux.simps)
  moreover have
   "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X (?Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := D, Doms := Uâ¦ˆ)"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_input_2)
  ultimately have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_2 I D U xs X (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_2)
  moreover have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_form (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_aux)
  ultimately have "snd (ipurge_fail_aux_t_out (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)) =
    ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_intro_2)
  moreover have "?Y = ipurge_fail_aux_t_in I D U xs X"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_in_def)
  ultimately show ?thesis
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_def)
qed

lemma ipurge_fail_aux_t_failures [rule_format]:
 "secure P I D âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
    ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X âˆˆ failures P"
proof -
  let ?Y = "â¦‡Pol = I, Map = D, Doms = U, List = xs, ListOp = None,
    Set = Xâ¦ˆ"
  have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y
    âˆˆ ipurge_fail_aux_t_set (?Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := Dâ¦ˆ)"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux_set del: ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux.simps)
  moreover have
   "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X (?Yâ¦‡Pol := I, Map := Dâ¦ˆ)"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_input_3)
  ultimately have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_inv_3 P I D xs X (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_invariance_3)
  moreover have "ipurge_fail_aux_t_form (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y)"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_form_aux)
  ultimately have "secure P I D âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
    ipurge_fail_aux_t_out (ipurge_fail_aux_t_aux ?Y) âˆˆ failures P"
   by (rule ipurge_fail_aux_t_intro_3)
  moreover have "?Y = ipurge_fail_aux_t_in I D U xs X"
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_in_def)
  ultimately show ?thesis
   by (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_def)
qed

lemma ipurge_tr_ref_aux_failures:
 "âŸ¦secure P I D; (xs, X) âˆˆ failures PâŸ§ âŸ¹
    (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs, ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X) âˆˆ failures P"
proof (drule ipurge_fail_aux_t_failures [where U = U], assumption,
 cases "ipurge_fail_aux_t I D U xs X")
qed (simp add: ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_tr [where X = X, symmetric]
 ipurge_fail_aux_t_eq_ref [symmetric])


subsection "Additional propaedeutic lemmas"

text â€¹
In what follows, additional lemmas required for the demonstration of the target security
conservation theorem are proven.

Here below is the proof of some properties of functions @{term ipurge_tr_aux} and
@{term ipurge_ref_aux}. Particularly, it is shown that in case an event list and its intransitive
purge for some set of domains are both traces of a secure process, and the purged list has a future
not affected by any purged event, then that future is also a future for the full event list.

\null
â€º

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_idem:
 "ipurge_tr_aux I D U (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_union [symmetric])

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_set:
 "set (ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs) âŠ† set xs"
proof (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp_all)
qed blast

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_nil [rule_format]:
  assumes A: "u âˆˆ U"
  shows "(âˆ€x âˆˆ set xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I) âŸ¶ ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs = []"
proof (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp, rule impI)
  fix x xs
  assume "(âˆ€x' âˆˆ set xs. (u, D x') âˆˆ I) âŸ¶ ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs = []"
  moreover assume B: "âˆ€x' âˆˆ set (xs @ [x]). (u, D x') âˆˆ I"
  ultimately have C: "ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs = []"
   by simp
  have "(u, D x) âˆˆ I"
   using B by simp
  moreover have "U âŠ† sinks_aux I D U xs"
   by (rule sinks_aux_subset)
  hence "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs"
   using A ..
  ultimately have "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (u, D x) âˆˆ I" ..
  hence "ipurge_tr_aux I D U (xs @ [x]) = ipurge_tr_aux I D U xs"
   by simp
  thus "ipurge_tr_aux I D U (xs @ [x]) = []"
   using C by simp
qed

lemma ipurge_tr_aux_del_failures [rule_format]:
  assumes S: "secure P I D"
  shows "(âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (u, D z) âˆ‰ I) âŸ¶
    (xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
    xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P âŸ¶
    (xs @ ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
proof (induction ys arbitrary: zs rule: rev_induct, simp, (rule impI)+)
  fix y ys zs
  assume
    A: "â‹€zs. (âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (u, D z) âˆ‰ I) âŸ¶
      (xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
      xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P âŸ¶
        (xs @ ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P" and
    B: "âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U (ys @ [y]). âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (u, D z) âˆ‰ I" and
    C: "(xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U (ys @ [y]) @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P" and
    D: "xs @ (ys @ [y]) âˆˆ traces P"
  show "(xs @ (ys @ [y]) @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
  proof (cases "âˆƒu âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U ys. (u, D y) âˆˆ I", simp_all (no_asm))
    case True
    have
     "(âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (u, D z) âˆ‰ I) âŸ¶
      (xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
      xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P âŸ¶
        (xs @ ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     using A .
    moreover have "âˆƒu âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U ys. (u, D y) âˆˆ I"
     using True by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
    hence E: "âˆ€u âˆˆ insert (D y) (sinks_aux_less I D U ys). âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs.
      (u, D z) âˆ‰ I"
     using B by (simp only: sinks_aux_less.simps if_True)
    hence "âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (u, D z) âˆ‰ I"
     by simp
    moreover have "(xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     using C and True by simp
    moreover have "(xs @ ys) @ [y] âˆˆ traces P"
     using D by simp
    hence "xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P"
     by (rule process_rule_2_traces)
    ultimately have "(xs @ ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     by simp
    hence "(zs, Z) âˆˆ futures P (xs @ ys)"
     by (simp add: futures_def)
    moreover have "(xs @ ys @ [y], {}) âˆˆ failures P"
     using D by (rule traces_failures)
    hence "([y], {}) âˆˆ futures P (xs @ ys)"
     by (simp add: futures_def)
    ultimately have "(y # ipurge_tr I D (D y) zs, ipurge_ref I D (D y) zs Z)
      âˆˆ futures P (xs @ ys)"
     using S by (simp add: secure_def)
    moreover have "ipurge_tr I D (D y) zs = zs"
     by (subst ipurge_tr_all, simp add: E)
    moreover have "ipurge_ref I D (D y) zs Z = Z"
     by (rule ipurge_ref_all, simp add: E)
    ultimately have "(y # zs, Z) âˆˆ futures P (xs @ ys)"
     by simp
    thus "(xs @ ys @ y # zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     by (simp add: futures_def)
  next
    case False
    have E:
     "(âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set (y # zs). (u, D z) âˆ‰ I) âŸ¶
      (xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ (y # zs), Z) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
      xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P âŸ¶
        (xs @ ys @ (y # zs), Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     using A .
    have F: "Â¬ (âˆƒu âˆˆ U âˆª sinks_aux_less I D U ys. (u, D y) âˆˆ I)"
     using False by (simp add: sinks_aux_sinks_aux_less)
    hence "âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (u, D z) âˆ‰ I"
     using B by (simp only: sinks_aux_less.simps if_False)
    moreover have "âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. (u, D y) âˆ‰ I"
     using F by simp
    ultimately have
     "âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux_less I D U ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set (y # zs). (u, D z) âˆ‰ I"
     by simp
    with E have
     "(xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ (y # zs), Z) âˆˆ failures P âŸ¶
      xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P âŸ¶
        (xs @ ys @ (y # zs), Z) âˆˆ failures P" ..
    moreover have "(xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D U ys @ (y # zs), Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     using C and False by simp
    moreover have "(xs @ ys) @ [y] âˆˆ traces P"
     using D by simp
    hence "xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P"
     by (rule process_rule_2_traces)
    ultimately show "(xs @ ys @ (y # zs), Z) âˆˆ failures P"
     by simp
  qed
qed

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_append:
 "ipurge_ref_aux I D U (xs @ ys) X = ipurge_ref_aux I D (sinks_aux I D U xs) ys X"
by (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_def sinks_aux_append)

lemma ipurge_ref_aux_empty [rule_format]:
  assumes
    A: "u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs" and
    B: "âˆ€x âˆˆ X. (u, D x) âˆˆ I"
  shows "ipurge_ref_aux I D U xs X = {}"
proof (rule equals0I, simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_def, erule conjE)
  fix x
  assume "x âˆˆ X"
  with B have "(u, D x) âˆˆ I" ..
  moreover assume "âˆ€u âˆˆ sinks_aux I D U xs. (u, D x) âˆ‰ I"
  hence "(u, D x) âˆ‰ I"
   using A ..
  ultimately show False
   by contradiction
qed

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the proof of some properties of functions @{term sinks}, @{term ipurge_tr}, and
@{term ipurge_ref}. Particularly, using the previous analogous result on function
@{term ipurge_tr_aux}, it is shown that in case an event list and its intransitive purge for some
domain are both traces of a secure process, and the purged list has a future not affected by any
purged event, then that future is also a future for the full event list.

\null
â€º

lemma sinks_idem:
 "sinks I D u (ipurge_tr I D u xs) = {}"
by (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp_all)

lemma sinks_elem [rule_format]:
 "v âˆˆ sinks I D u xs âŸ¶ (âˆƒx âˆˆ set xs. v = D x)"
by (induction xs rule: rev_induct, simp_all)

lemma ipurge_tr_append:
 "ipurge_tr I D u (xs @ ys) =
  ipurge_tr I D u xs @ ipurge_tr_aux I D (insert u (sinks I D u xs)) ys"
proof (simp add: sinks_aux_single_dom [symmetric]
 ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom [symmetric])
qed (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_append)

lemma ipurge_tr_idem:
 "ipurge_tr I D u (ipurge_tr I D u xs) = ipurge_tr I D u xs"
by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom [symmetric] ipurge_tr_aux_idem)

lemma ipurge_tr_set:
 "set (ipurge_tr I D u xs) âŠ† set xs"
by (simp add: ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom [symmetric] ipurge_tr_aux_set)

lemma ipurge_tr_del_failures [rule_format]:
  assumes
    S: "secure P I D" and
    A: "âˆ€v âˆˆ sinks I D u ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ Z âˆª set zs. (v, D z) âˆ‰ I" and
    B: "(xs @ ipurge_tr I D u ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P" and
    C: "xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P"
  shows "(xs @ ys @ zs, Z) âˆˆ failures P"
proof (rule ipurge_tr_aux_del_failures [OF S _ _ C, where U = "{u}"])
qed (simp add: A sinks_aux_less_single_dom, simp add: B ipurge_tr_aux_single_dom)

lemma ipurge_tr_del_traces [rule_format]:
  assumes
    S: "secure P I D" and
    A: "âˆ€v âˆˆ sinks I D u ys. âˆ€z âˆˆ set zs. (v, D z) âˆ‰ I" and
    B: "xs @ ipurge_tr I D u ys @ zs âˆˆ traces P" and
    C: "xs @ ys âˆˆ traces P"
  shows "xs @ ys @ zs âˆˆ traces P"
proof (rule failures_traces [where X = "{}"],
 rule ipurge_tr_del_failures [OF S _ _ C, where u = u])
qed (simp add: A, rule traces_failures [OF B])

lemma ipurge_ref_append:
 "ipurge_ref I D u (xs @ ys) X =
  ipurge_ref_aux I D (insert u (sinks I D u xs)) ys X"
proof (simp add: sinks_aux_single_dom [symmetric]
 ipurge_ref_aux_single_dom [symmetric])
qed (simp add: ipurge_ref_aux_append)

lemma ipurge_ref_distrib_inter:
 "ipurge_ref I D u xs (X âˆ© Y) = ipurge_ref I D u xs X âˆ© ipurge_ref I D u xs Y"
proof (simp add: ipurge_ref_def)
qed blast

lemma ipurge_ref_distrib_union:
 "ipurge_ref I D u xs (X âˆª Y) = ipurge_ref I D u xs X âˆª ipurge_ref I D u xs Y"
proof (simp add: ipurge_ref_def)
qed blast

lemma ipurge_ref_subset:
 "ipurge_ref I D u xs X âŠ† X"
by (subst ipurge_ref_def, rule subsetI, simp)

lemma ipurge_ref_subset_union:
 "ipurge_ref I D u xs (X âˆª Y) âŠ† X âˆª ipurge_ref I D u xs Y"
proof (simp add: ipurge_ref_def)
qed blast

lemma ipurge_ref_subset_insert:
 "ipurge_ref I D u xs (insert x X) âŠ† insert x (ipurge_ref I D u xs X)"
by (simp only: insert_def ipurge_ref_subset_union)

lemma ipurge_ref_empty [rule_format]:
  assumes
    A: "v = u âˆ¨ v âˆˆ sinks I D u xs" and
    B: "âˆ€x âˆˆ X. (v, D x) âˆˆ I"
  shows "ipurge_ref I D u xs X = {}"
proof (subst ipurge_ref_aux_single_dom [symmetric],
 rule ipurge_ref_aux_empty [of v])
  show "v âˆˆ sinks_aux I D {u} xs"
   using A by (simp add: sinks_aux_single_dom)
next
  fix x
  assume "x âˆˆ X"
  with B show "(v, D x) âˆˆ I" ..
qed

text â€¹
\null

Finally, in what follows, properties @{term process_prop_1}, @{term process_prop_5}, and
@{term process_prop_6} of processes (cf. \cite{R2}) are put into the form of introduction rules.

\null
â€º

lemma process_rule_1:
 "([], {}) âˆˆ failures P"
proof (simp add: failures_def)
  have "Rep_process P âˆˆ process_set" (is "?P' âˆˆ _")
   by (rule Rep_process)
  thus "([], {}) âˆˆ fst ?P'"
   by (simp add: process_set_def process_prop_1_def)
qed

lemma process_rule_5 [rule_format]:
 "xs âˆˆ divergences P âŸ¶ xs @ [x] âˆˆ divergences P"
proof (simp add: divergences_def)
  have "Rep_process P âˆˆ process_set" (is "?P' âˆˆ _")
   by (rule Rep_process)
  hence "âˆ€xs x. xs âˆˆ snd ?P' âŸ¶ xs @ [x] âˆˆ snd ?P'"
   by (simp add: process_set_def process_prop_5_def)
  thus "xs âˆˆ snd ?P' âŸ¶ xs @ [x] âˆˆ snd ?P'"
   by blast
qed

lemma process_rule_6 [rule_format]:
 "xs âˆˆ divergences P âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P"
proof (simp add: failures_def divergences_def)
  have "Rep_process P âˆˆ process_set" (is "?P' âˆˆ _")
   by (rule Rep_process)
  hence "âˆ€xs X. xs âˆˆ snd ?P' âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ fst ?P'"
   by (simp add: process_set_def process_prop_6_def)
  thus "xs âˆˆ snd ?P' âŸ¶ (xs, X) âˆˆ fst ?P'"
   by blast
qed

end

Theory SequentialComposition

(*  Title:       Conservation of CSP Noninterference Security under Sequential Composition
    Author:      Pasquale Noce
                 Security Certification Specialist at Arjo Systems, Italy
                 pasquale dot noce dot lavoro at gmail dot com
                 pasquale dot noce at arjosystems dot com
*)

section "Sequential composition and noninterference security"

theory SequentialComposition
imports Propaedeutics
begin

text â€¹
\null

This section formalizes the definitions of sequential processes and sequential composition given in
\cite{R4}, and then proves that under the assumptions discussed above, noninterference security is
conserved under sequential composition for any pair of processes sharing an alphabet that contains
successful termination. Finally, this result is generalized to an arbitrary list of processes.
â€º


subsection "Sequential processes"

text â€¹
In \cite{R4}, a \emph{sequential process} is defined as a process whose alphabet contains successful
termination. Since sequential composition applies to sequential processes, the first problem put by
the formalization of this operation is that of finding a suitable way to represent such a process.

A simple but effective strategy is to identify it with a process having alphabet @{typ "'a option"},
where @{typ 'a} is the native type of its ordinary (i.e. distinct from termination) events. Then,
ordinary events will be those matching pattern â€¹Some _â€º, whereas successful termination will
be denoted by the special event @{term None}. This means that the \emph{sentences} of a sequential
process, defined in \cite{R4} as the traces after which the process can terminate successfully, will
be nothing but the event lists @{term xs} such that @{term "xs @ [None]"} is a trace (which implies
that @{term xs} is a trace as well).

Once a suitable representation of successful termination has been found, the next step is to
formalize the properties of sequential processes related to this event, expressing them in terms of
the selected representation. The first of the resulting predicates, â€¹weakly_sequentialâ€º, is
the minimum required for allowing the identification of event @{term None} with successful
termination, namely that @{term None} may occur in a trace as its last event only. The second
predicate, â€¹sequentialâ€º, following what Hoare does in \cite{R4}, extends the first predicate
with an additional requirement, namely that whenever the process can engage in event @{term None},
it cannot engage in any other event. A simple counterexample shows that this requirement does not
imply the first one: a process whose traces are @{term "{[], [None], [None, None]}"} satisfies the
second requirement, but not the first one.

Moreover, here below is the definition of a further predicate, â€¹secure_terminationâ€º, which
applies to a security policy rather than to a process, and is satisfied just in case the policy does
not allow event @{term None} to be affected by confidential events, viz. by ordinary events not
allowed to affect some event in the alphabet. Interestingly, this property, which will prove to be
necessary for the target theorem to hold, is nothing but the CSP counterpart of a condition required
for a security type system to enforce termination-sensitive noninterference security of programs,
namely that program termination must not depend on confidential data (cf. \cite{R5}, section 9.2.6).

\null
â€º

definition sentences :: "'a option process â‡’ 'a option list set" where
"sentences P â‰¡ {xs. xs @ [None] âˆˆ traces P}"

definition weakly_sequential :: "'a option process â‡’ bool" where
"weakly_sequential P â‰¡
  âˆ€xs âˆˆ traces P. None âˆ‰ set (butlast xs)"

definition sequential :: "'a option process â‡’ bool" where
"sequential P â‰¡
  (âˆ€xs âˆˆ traces P. None âˆ‰ set (butlast xs)) âˆ§
  (âˆ€xs âˆˆ sentences P. next_events P xs = {None})"

definition secure_termination :: "('d Ã— 'd) set â‡’ ('a option â‡’ 'd) â‡’ bool" where
"secure_termination I D â‰¡
  âˆ€x. (D x, D None) âˆˆ I âˆ§ x â‰  None âŸ¶ (âˆ€u âˆˆ range D. (D x, u) âˆˆ I)"

text â€¹
\null

Here below is the proof of some useful lemmas involving the constants just defined. Particularly, it
is proven that process sequentiality is indeed stronger than weak sequentiality, and a sentence of a
refusals union closed (cf. \cite{R3}), sequential process admits the set of all the ordinary events
of the process as a refusal. The use of the latter lemma in the proof of the target security
conservation theorem is the reason why the theorem requires to assume that the first of the
processes to be composed be refusals union closed (cf. below).

\null
â€º

lemma seq_implies_weakly_seq:
 "sequential P âŸ¹ weakly_sequential P"
by (simp add: weakly_sequential_def sequential_def)

lemma weakly_seq_sentences_none:
  assumes
    WS: "weakly_sequential P" and
    A: "xs âˆˆ sentences P"
  shows "None âˆ‰ set xs"
proof -
  have "âˆ€xs âˆˆ traces P. None âˆ‰ set (butlast xs)"
   using WS by (simp add: weakly_sequential_def)
  moreover have "xs @ [None] âˆˆ traces P"
   using A by (simp add: sentences_def)
  ultimately have "None âˆ‰ set (butlast (xs @ [None]))" ..
  thus ?thesis
   by simp
qed

lemma seq_sentences_none:
  assumes
    S: "sequential P" and
    A: "xs âˆˆ sentences P" and
    B: "xs @ y # ys âˆˆ traces P"
  shows "y = None"
proof -
  have "âˆ€xs âˆˆ sentences P. next_events P xs = {None}"
   using S by (simp add: sequential_def)
  hence "next_events P xs = {None}"
   using A ..
  moreover have "(xs @ [y]) @ ys âˆˆ traces P"
   using B by simp
  hence "xs @ [y] âˆˆ traces P"
   by (rule process_rule_2_traces)
  hence "y âˆˆ next_events P xs"
   by (simp add: next_events_def)
  ultimately show ?thesis
   by simp
qed

lemma seq_sentences_ref:
  assumes
    A: "ref_union_closed P" and
    B: "sequential P" and
    C: "xs âˆˆ sentences P"
  shows "(xs, {x. x â‰  None}) âˆˆ failures P"
    (is "(_, ?X) âˆˆ _")
proof -
  have "(âˆƒX. X âˆˆ singleton_set ?X) âŸ¶
    (âˆ€X âˆˆ singleton_set ?X. (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P) âŸ¶
    (xs, â‹ƒX âˆˆ singleton_set ?X. X) âˆˆ failures P"
   using A by (simp add: ref_union_closed_def)
  moreover have "âˆƒx. x âˆˆ ?X"
   by blast
  hence "âˆƒX. X âˆˆ singleton_set ?X"
   by (simp add: singleton_set_some)
  ultimately have "(âˆ€X âˆˆ singleton_set ?X. (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P) âŸ¶
    (xs, â‹ƒX âˆˆ singleton_set ?X. X) âˆˆ failures P" ..
  moreover have "âˆ€X âˆˆ singleton_set ?X. (xs, X) âˆˆ failures P"
  proof (rule ballI, simp add: singleton_set_def del: not_None_eq,
   erule exE, erule conjE, simp (no_asm_simp))
    fix x :: "'a option"
    assume D: "x â‰  None"
    have "xs @ [None] âˆˆ traces P"
     using C by (simp add: sentences_def)
    hence "xs âˆˆ traces P"
     by (rule process_rule_2_traces)
    hence "(xs, {}) âˆˆ failures P"
     by (rule traces_failures)
    hence "(xs @ [x], {}) âˆˆ failures P âˆ¨ (xs, {x}) âˆˆ failures P"
     by (rule process_rule_4)
    thus "(xs, {x}) âˆˆ failures P"
    proof (rule disjE, rule_tac ccontr, simp_all)
      assume "(xs @ [x], {}) âˆˆ failures P"
      hence "xs @ [x] âˆˆ traces P"
       by (rule failures_traces)
      with B and C have "x = None"
       by (rule seq_sentences_none)
      thus False
       using D by contradiction
    qed
  qed
  ultimately have "(xs, â‹ƒX âˆˆ singleton_set ?X. X) âˆˆ failures P" ..
  thus ?thesis
   by (simp only: singleton_set_union)
qed


subsection "Sequential composition"

text â€¹
In what follows, the definition of the failures resulting from the sequential composition of two
processes @{term P}, @{term Q} given in \cite{R4} is formalized as the inductive definition of set
â€¹seq_comp_failures P Qâ€º. Then, the sequential composition of @{term P} and @{term Q},
denoted by means of notation â€¹P ; Qâ€º following \cite{R4}, is defined as the process having
â€¹seq_comp_failures P Qâ€º as failures set and the empty set as divergences set.

For the sake of generality, this definition is based on the mere implicit assumption that the input
processes be weakly sequential, rather than sequential. This slightly complicates things, since the
sentences of process @{term P} may number further events in addition to @{term None} in their
future.

Therefore, the resulting refusals of a sentence @{term xs} of @{term P} will have the form
@{term "insert None X âˆ© Y"}, where @{term X} is a refusal of @{term xs} in @{term P} and @{term Y}
is an initial refusal of @{term Q} (cf. rule â€¹SCF_R2â€º). In fact, after @{term xs}, process
â€¹P ; Qâ€º must be able to refuse @{term None} if @{term Q} is, whereas it cannot refuse an
ordinary event unless both @{term P} and @{term Q}, in their respective states, can.

Moreover, a trace @{term xs} of â€¹P ; Qâ€º may result from different combinations of a sentence
of @{term P} with a trace of @{term Q}. Thus, in order that the refusals of â€¹P ; Qâ€º be
closed under set union, the union of any two refusals of @{term xs} must still be a refusal (cf.
rule â€¹SCF_R4â€º). Indeed, this property will prove to be sufficient to ensure that for any two
processes whose refusals are closed under set union, their sequential composition still be such,
which is what is expected for any process of practical significance (cf. \cite{R3}).

According to the definition given in \cite{R4}, a divergence of â€¹P ; Qâ€º is either a
divergence of @{term P}, or the concatenation of a sentence of @{term P} with a divergence of
@{term Q}. Apparently, this definition does not match the formal one stated here below, which
identifies the divergences set of â€¹P ; Qâ€º with the empty set. Nonetheless, as remarked
above, sequential composition does not make sense unless the input processes are weakly sequential,
since this is the minimum required to confer the meaning of successful termination on the
corresponding alphabet symbol. But a weakly sequential process cannot have any divergence, so that
the two definitions are actually equivalent. In fact, a divergence is a trace such that, however it
